9561.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This word is a negative compound formed from the negative particle "a-" and "sampavedhī", which itself is derived from the verb sampavedhati (to shake, tremble). The meaning "unshakable" fits the context of a firmly embedded pillar.
9561.sutta_1: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, indakhīlo vā ayokhīlo vā gambhīranemo sunikhāto acalo asampavedhī;
9561.example_1: Suppose there was a boundary pillar or an iron pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.

11604.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, `ādiyituṃ` is used with `adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ`, meaning "what is not given, counted as theft". Thus, it specifically means "to take (what is not given), i.e., to steal".
11604.sutta_1: Abhabbo, āvuso, khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṁ jīvitā voropetuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṁ kāme paribhuñjituṁ, seyyathāpi pubbe āgārikabhūto; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu chandāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu dosāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu mohāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu bhayāgatiṁ gantuṁ.
11604.example_1: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they used to as a lay person. And they can’t make decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, or cowardice.

11234.meaning_1: (while) being a householder, leading a householder's life; as a layperson
11234.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In dn29:26.8, it refers to the state of the arahant *before* becoming a bhikkhu, when they were still a layperson/householder.
11234.sutta_1: Abhabbo, āvuso, khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṁ jīvitā voropetuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṁ kāme paribhuñjituṁ, seyyathāpi pubbe āgārikabhūto; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu chandāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu dosāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu mohāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu bhayāgatiṁ gantuṁ.
11234.example_1: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they used to as a lay person. And they can’t make decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, or cowardice.

40146.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This word refers to the act or process of answering a question. It appears in DN29 as a section title, indicating the explanation or answer provided within that part of the text. It is a compound of pañhā (question) and byākaraṇa (explanation, answer). The compound type is chaṭṭhī tappurisa (genitive tatpuruṣa), meaning "answer of the question".

2418.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Used with ñāṇadassana (knowledge and vision) to mean 'boundless'.
2418.sutta_1: ‘atītaṁ kho addhānaṁ ārabbha samaṇo gotamo atīrakaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paññapeti, no ca kho anāgataṁ addhānaṁ ārabbha atīrakaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paññapeti, tayidaṁ kiṁsu tayidaṁ kathaṁsū’ti?
2418.example_1: ‘The ascetic Gotama demonstrates boundless knowledge and vision of the past, but not of the future. What’s up with that?’

1598.meaning_1: who is preoccupied with something else; who is engaged with another thing
1598.meaning_lit: having other things arranged/placed; directed elsewhere
1598.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word aññavihitaka is an adjective formed from the compound aññavihita with the taddhita suffix -ka. The base compound aññavihita is likely a kammadhāraya meaning "arranged/placed otherwise". The suffix -ka creates an adjective with a sense of "having" or "relating to", resulting in the meaning "having other things arranged/placed" or "preoccupied/engaged with something else". In the contextual sentence, it modifies ñāṇadassana (knowledge and vision), describing a type of knowledge and vision that is directed towards, or preoccupied with, something other than its proper object.
1598.sutta_1: Te ca aññatitthiyā paribbājakā aññavihitakena ñāṇadassanena aññavihitakaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paññapetabbaṁ maññanti yathariva bālā abyattā.
1598.example_1: Those wanderers, like incompetent fools, seem to imagine that one kind of knowledge and vision can be demonstrated by means of another kind of knowledge and vision.

39982.meaning_1: to be made known; to be declared; to be demonstrated; to be prescribed; to be established
39982.meaning_lit: fit to be caused to know
39982.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is the potential participle of the causative verb paññāpeti, meaning "to cause to know" or various extensions like "to make known, declare, demonstrate, prescribe, establish". The suffix -tabba indicates suitability or necessity. In the contextual sentence, it means "to be demonstrated".
39982.sutta_1: Te ca aññatitthiyā paribbājakā aññavihitakena ñāṇadassanena aññavihitakaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paññapetabbaṁ maññanti yathariva bālā abyattā.
39982.example_1: Those wanderers, like incompetent fools, seem to imagine that one kind of knowledge and vision can be demonstrated by means of another kind of knowledge and vision.

48668.meaning_1: born from awakening; produced by enlightenment
48668.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word bodhija is a compound of bodhi (feminine) and ja (born from). The pañcamī case of bodhi is bodhiyā, hence the compound construction reflects a pañcamī tappurisa, meaning "born from bodhi". In the contextual sentence, it modifies ñāṇaṁ (knowledge), describing knowledge that arises from or is characteristic of awakening.
48668.sutta_1: Anāgatañca kho addhānaṁ ārabbha tathāgatassa bodhijaṁ ñāṇaṁ uppajjati:
48668.example_1: Regarding the future, the Realized One has the knowledge born of awakening:

46868.meaning_1: associated with the past; connected with the past
46868.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This adjective describes views or theories that relate to or are based on the past. The term is commonly found in the Brahmajāla Sutta (DN 1) where the Buddha categorizes various philosophical views, particularly those related to speculation about the past (pubbanta) or the future (aparanta). sahagata means "accompanied by" or "associated with", and compounds with sahagata often take the instrumental case for the first element (Tatiyā Tappurisa), as shown in the compound construction field.
46868.sutta_1: Yepi te, cunda, pubbantasahagatā diṭṭhinissayā, tepi vo mayā byākatā, yathā te byākātabbā.
46868.example_1: Cunda, I have explained to you as they should be explained the views that some rely on regarding the past.

48799.meaning_1: should be explained; should be defined; should be described
48799.construction: vi > vy > by + ā + √kar > kā + tabba
48799.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence "yathā te byākātabbā", byākātabbā is the plural form modifying "diṭṭhinissayā" (views). It means "as they should be explained". This entry specifically covers the meaning related to explaining, defining, or describing, as distinct from the meaning related to answering or replying covered by byākātabba 1.
48799.sutta_1: Yepi te, cunda, pubbantasahagatā diṭṭhinissayā, tepi vo mayā byākatā, yathā te byākātabbā.
48799.example_1: Cunda, I have explained to you as they should be explained the views that some rely on regarding the past.

6287.meaning_1: associated with the future; connected with the future
6287.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the context 'aparantasahagatā diṭṭhinissayā', it refers to speculative views or beliefs that are concerned with or pertain to the future.
6287.sutta_1: Yepi te, cunda, aparantasahagatā diṭṭhinissayā, tepi vo mayā byākatā, yathā te byākātabbā.
6287.example_1: I have explained to you as they should be explained the views that some rely on regarding the future.

64098.meaning_1: very pleasing; very inspiring confidence; impressive
64098.construction:
su + pa + sāde + a + ika
su + pāsādika
64098.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, 'supāsādiko dhammapariyāyo' means 'an impressive exposition of the teaching'.
64098.sutta_1: supāsādiko vatāyaṁ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo, ko nāmāyaṁ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo”ti?
64098.example_1: it is very impressive. Sir, what is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

55488.meaning_1: Name of a Sutta in the Dīgha Nikāya (DN 30)
55488.meaning_lit: Discourse concerning the marks (of a great man); Sutta on the characteristics
55488.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is the thirtieth and final sutta of the Dīgha Nikāya, dealing with the 32 marks of a Great Man (mahāpurisalakkhaṇa).

75795.construction: adhi > adhy > ajjh + ā + vasa + ti
75795.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The contextual sentence translates ajjhāvasati as "was living in", which aligns with meaning_1 from ajjhāvasati 1 in the related entries. However, this entry is specifically labelled ajjhāvasati 3 with the meaning "holds a position". The translation suggests meaning_1 of ajjhāvasati 1 might be more appropriate in context, but I will keep the provided meaning_1 for ajjhāvasati 3 and add a meaning_2 based on the translation provided with the context sentence.
75795.sutta_1: Tena kho pana samayena brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ukkaṭṭhaṁ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṁ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ sadhaññaṁ rājabhoggaṁ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṁ rājadāyaṁ brahmadeyyaṁ.
75795.example_1: Now at that time the brahmin Pokkharasāti was living in Ukkaṭṭhā. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.

69534.meaning_1: who rolls back the veil (of illusion) (in); (comm) who uncovers the hindrances
69534.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Used in the Sutta to describe the Buddha as the one who dispels ignorance or uncovers hindrances in the world.
69534.example_1: so imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati. sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado [vivaṭacchado, vivattacchado] .

64614.meaning_1: well divided inside; evenly separated within
64614.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This compound adjective describes the wheels on the soles of the Buddha's feet in the Mahāpurisalakkhaṇa Sutta (DN 30), indicating that the patterns (spokes, rim, hub) are clearly and distinctly marked or separated within the design on the sole.
64614.sutta_1: Heṭṭhāpādatalesu cakkāni jātāni honti sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni suvibhattantarāni.
64614.example_1: on the soles of his feet there are thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail and well divided inside.

22281.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, it describes the hair (lomāni) of the Great Man as being coiled or curled. The reading kuṇḍalāvattāni is the neuter plural form agreeing with lomāni.
22281.example_1: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso āyatapaṇhi hoti … dīghaṅguli hoti… mudutalunahatthapādo hoti… jālahatthapādo hoti… ussaṅkhapādo hoti… eṇijaṅgho hoti… ṭhitakova anonamanto ubhohi pāṇitalehi jaṇṇukāni parimasati parimajjati… kosohitavatthaguyho hoti… suvaṇṇavaṇṇo hoti kañcanasannibhattaco… sukhumacchavi hoti, sukhumattā chaviyā rajojallaṃ kāye na upalimpati… ekekalomo hoti, ekekāni lomāni lomakūpesu jātāni… uddhaggalomo hoti, uddhaggāni lomāni jātāni nīlāni añjanavaṇṇāni kuṇḍalāvaṭṭāni [kuṇḍalāvattāni (bahūsu)] dakkhiṇāvaṭṭakajātāni [dakkhiṇāvattakajātāni] … brahmujugatto hoti… sattussado hoti… sīhapubbaddhakāyo hoti… citantaraṃso [pitantaraṃso] hoti… nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo hoti, yāvatakvassa kāyo tāvatakvassa byāmo yāvatakvassa byāmo tāvatakvassa kāyo… samavaṭṭakkhandho hoti… rasaggasaggī hoti… sīhahanu hoti… cattālīsadanto hoti … samadanto hoti… aviraḷadanto hoti… susukkadāṭho hoti… pahūtajivho hoti… brahmassaro hoti karavīkabhāṇī… abhinīlanetto hoti… gopakhumo hoti… uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā hoti, odātā mudutūlasannibhā. yampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā hoti, odātā mudutūlasannibhā, idampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.

31719.meaning_1: growing turning to the right; sprouting curling clockwise
31719.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This word describes the hairs of the Great Man (mahāpurisa) as being coiled or curled clockwise. The compound combines dakkhiṇa (right), āvattaka (turning/curling), and jāta (grown/arisen). It functions as an adjective describing the manner in which the hairs have grown.
31719.example_1: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso āyatapaṇhi hoti … dīghaṅguli hoti… mudutalunahatthapādo hoti… jālahatthapādo hoti… ussaṅkhapādo hoti… eṇijaṅgho hoti… ṭhitakova anonamanto ubhohi pāṇitalehi jaṇṇukāni parimasati parimajjati… kosohitavatthaguyho hoti… suvaṇṇavaṇṇo hoti kañcanasannibhattaco… sukhumacchavi hoti, sukhumattā chaviyā rajojallaṃ kāye na upalimpati… ekekalomo hoti, ekekāni lomāni lomakūpesu jātāni… uddhaggalomo hoti, uddhaggāni lomāni jātāni nīlāni añjanavaṇṇāni kuṇḍalāvaṭṭāni [kuṇḍalāvattāni (bahūsu)] dakkhiṇāvaṭṭakajātāni [dakkhiṇāvattakajātāni] … brahmujugatto hoti… sattussado hoti… sīhapubbaddhakāyo hoti… citantaraṃso [pitantaraṃso] hoti… nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo hoti, yāvatakvassa kāyo tāvatakvassa byāmo yāvatakvassa byāmo tāvatakvassa kāyo… samavaṭṭakkhandho hoti… rasaggasaggī hoti… sīhahanu hoti… cattālīsadanto hoti … samadanto hoti… aviraḷadanto hoti… susukkadāṭho hoti… pahūtajivho hoti… brahmassaro hoti karavīkabhāṇī… abhinīlanetto hoti… gopakhumo hoti… uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā hoti, odātā mudutūlasannibhā. yampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā hoti, odātā mudutūlasannibhā, idampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.

20494.meaning_1: speaking like a karavīka bird; having a voice like a karavīka bird
20494.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The compound `karavīkabhāṇī` is a bahubbīhi compound describing someone who possesses the characteristic of speaking like a karavīka bird, known for its beautiful voice. The first part `karavīka` is likely in the accusative case as the object of the implied verbal action in `bhāṇī` (speaking).
20494.example_1: He has the voice of the Divinity, like a cuckoo’s call.

19327.meaning_lit: state of having been done; done-ness
19327.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the context, 'kaṭattā' is the ablative singular of 'kaṭattaṃ', meaning 'due to the performance' or 'because of having done'. It refers to the act of performing the deeds mentioned.
19327.sutta_1: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
19327.example_1: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

32269.meaning_1: giving and sharing; offering and distributing
32269.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, dānasaṃvibhāga is listed as one of the skillful behaviours (kusalesu dhammesu) cultivated by the Tathāgata in past lives. It appears in the locative singular form "dānasaṃvibhāge".
32269.sutta_1: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṁ jātiṁ purimaṁ bhavaṁ purimaṁ niketaṁ pubbe manussabhūto samāno daḷhasamādāno ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, avatthitasamādāno kāyasucarite vacīsucarite manosucarite dānasaṁvibhāge sīlasamādāne uposathupavāse matteyyatāya petteyyatāya sāmaññatāya brahmaññatāya kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitāya aññataraññataresu ca adhikusalesu dhammesu.
32269.example_1: In some past lives, past existences, past abodes the Realized One was reborn as a human being. He firmly and persistently undertook skillful behaviors such as good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, giving and sharing, taking precepts, observing the sabbath, paying due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in the family, and various other things pertaining to skillful behaviors.

63193.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word sīlasamādānaṃ is used in the contextual sentence as one of the kusalesu dhammesu (skillful behaviours) undertaken by the Tathāgata in past lives. It refers to the practice of formally taking on ethical precepts or vows.
63193.sutta_1: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṁ jātiṁ purimaṁ bhavaṁ purimaṁ niketaṁ pubbe manussabhūto samāno daḷhasamādāno ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, avatthitasamādāno kāyasucarite vacīsucarite manosucarite dānasaṁvibhāge sīlasamādāne uposathupavāse matteyyatāya petteyyatāya sāmaññatāya brahmaññatāya kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitāya aññataraññataresu ca adhikusalesu dhammesu.
63193.example_1: In some past lives, past existences, past abodes the Realized One was reborn as a human being. He firmly and persistently undertook skillful behaviors such as good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, giving and sharing, taking precepts, observing the sabbath, paying due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in the family, and various other things pertaining to skillful behaviors.

16530.meaning_1: observance of the full moon or new moon
16530.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, uposathupavāsa is listed among various skillful behaviors (kusalesu dhammesu) undertaken by the Buddha in past lives. It refers to the practice of observing the Uposatha day precepts/fast.
16530.sutta_1: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṁ jātiṁ purimaṁ bhavaṁ purimaṁ niketaṁ pubbe manussabhūto samāno daḷhasamādāno ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, avatthitasamādāno kāyasucarite vacīsucarite manosucarite dānasaṁvibhāge sīlasamādāne uposathupavāse matteyyatāya petteyyatāya sāmaññatāya brahmaññatāya kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitāya aññataraññataresu ca adhikusalesu dhammesu.
16530.example_1: In some past lives, past existences, past abodes the Realized One was reborn as a human being. He firmly and persistently undertook skillful behaviors such as good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, giving and sharing, taking precepts, observing the sabbath, paying due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in the family, and various other things pertaining to skillful behaviors.

3142.meaning_1: more skillful; higher skillful; superior skillful
3142.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Meaning in context: referring to qualities or actions that are considered "higher" or "more" skillful than basic ones, often implying a progressive development of skillful practices.
3142.sutta_1: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṁ jātiṁ purimaṁ bhavaṁ purimaṁ niketaṁ pubbe manussabhūto samāno daḷhasamādāno ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, avatthitasamādāno kāyasucarite vacīsucarite manosucarite dānasaṁvibhāge sīlasamādāne uposathupavāse matteyyatāya petteyyatāya sāmaññatāya brahmaññatāya kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitāya aññataraññataresu ca adhikusalesu dhammesu.
3142.example_1: In some past lives, past existences, past abodes the Realized One was reborn as a human being. He firmly and persistently undertook skillful behaviors such as good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, giving and sharing, taking precepts, observing the sabbath, paying due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in the family, and various other things pertaining to skillful behaviors.

15462.meaning_1: fact of having accumulated; fact of having collected
15462.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, "upacitattā" is the ablative/instrumental case, meaning "due to the fact of having accumulated" or "because of the accumulation". It is used in parallel with other abstract nouns denoting the state or fact of performing/having performed deeds.
15462.sutta_1: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
15462.example_1: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

17151.meaning_1: fact of being widespread; fact of being prevalent
17151.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, ussannattā is used in the instrumental case, meaning "due to the fact of being heaped up" or "due to the fact of being abundant/extensive", aligning with the provided meaning.
17151.sutta_1: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
17151.example_1: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

68440.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, `vipulattā` (ablative case of vipulatta) is used to describe the quality of "kammassa" (the deed), indicating that the deed was extensive, massive, or abundant, contributing to the subsequent rebirth in a good realm.
68440.sutta_1: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
68440.example_1: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

37995.meaning_1: untroubled; safe; undisturbed; free from difficulties/troubles
37995.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The adjective nirabbuda, meaning "untroubled" or "safe", is formed from the negative prefix nir- (Pāli nis-) and abbuda in the sense of "trouble" or "difficulty". The contextual sentence "khemaṁ sivaṁ nirabbudaṁ" (safe, blessed, and untroubled) supports this interpretation.
37995.sutta_1: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṁ iddhaṁ phītaṁ khemaṁ sivaṁ nirabbudaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
37995.example_1: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, and untroubled—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

65144.meaning_1: purity, reliance on ethical conduct and observing the uposatha
65144.meaning_lit: observance day related to purity and reliance on ethical conduct
65144.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The compound likely breaks down as (soceyya + sīlālaya) + uposatha, where soceyya and sīlālaya form a dvanda compound modifying uposatha as a chatṭhī tappurisa. Sīlālaya itself is likely a locative tappurisa (reliance on sīla). The translation in the contextual sentence simplifies the compound structure by listing the components.
65144.example_1: purity, precepts, and observing the sabbath;

70405.meaning_1: soothsayer; interpreter of signs; diviner; one who knows the characteristics
70405.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence 'veyyañjanikā' (plural of veyyañjaniko) refers to 'soothsayers' who predicted the future based on signs.

59436.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, Samappatiṭṭhassa is the genitive singular form, agreeing with an implied noun (like 'puggalassa' - of a person). It means 'for the one who is evenly established'. The compound is likely formed from sama ('even', 'same') and patiṭṭhā ('establishment') or patiṭṭhita ('established', pp), describing someone who has even establishment. It functions as a Bahuvrīhi adjective.
59436.example_1: that there is no stopping one of such even tread,

23517.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence "Samappatiṭṭhassa na hoti khambhanā", khambhanā signifies the absence of rigidity, obstruction, or paralysis for someone who is firmly established or has a steady footing (samappatiṭṭhassa).
23517.example_1: that there is no stopping one of such even tread,

29752.meaning_lit: showing that meaning; illuminating that meaning
29752.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Compound of tad (that), attha (meaning), and jotaka (showing, illuminating). Functions as an adjective modifying lakkhaṇa (mark). In the context "Taṁ lakkhaṇaṁ bhavati tadatthajotakaṁ", it means "That mark is showing that meaning", implying the mark serves to clarify or indicate a specific meaning mentioned earlier.
29752.example_1: That’s the meaning shown by this mark.

16759.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This compound lists three types of fear or danger: ubbega (anxiety, agitation), uttāsa (terror, dread), and bhaya (fear, danger). The contextual sentence uses it collectively, translated as 'threats, terror, and danger', reflecting the composite nature of the word.
16759.sutta_1: bahujanassa sukhāvaho ahosi, ubbegauttāsabhayaṁ apanuditā, dhammikañca rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidhātā, saparivārañca dānaṁ adāsi.
16759.example_1: He conveyed happiness to many people, eliminating threats, terror, and danger, providing just protection and security, and giving gifts with all the trimmings.

6229.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In this context, apanuditā is used predicatively or in apposition to the subject, meaning "one who eliminated". It takes the accusative object ubbegauttāsabhayaṁ.
6229.sutta_1: bahujanassa sukhāvaho ahosi, ubbegauttāsabhayaṁ apanuditā, dhammikañca rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidhātā, saparivārañca dānaṁ adāsi.
6229.example_1: He conveyed happiness to many people, eliminating threats, terror, and danger, providing just protection and security, and giving gifts with all the trimmings.

51803.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence "Mahāparivāro hoti", the word functions as a predicate adjective meaning "he is one who has a great retinue" or "he has a large following". This confirms its Bahubbīhi nature.

50368.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, "bhogiyā" is used as a plural masculine noun alongside "rājāno" and "kumārā". It refers to a class of people who receive revenues or benefits, likely from the state or a ruler, hence "tax beneficiaries" or "recipients of revenues".
50368.sutta_1: mahāssa honti parivārā brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamajānapadā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā amaccā pārisajjā rājāno bhogiyā kumārā.
50368.example_1: of brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

46961.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This lemma `puratthā 2` represents the temporal meaning 'in the past, previously', distinguishing it from `puratthā 1` which means 'in an eastern direction'. Both forms derive from `pura` with the suffix `-tthā` (Skt. `-tāt`). The contextual sentence 'Pure puratthā purimāsu jātisu' clearly uses `puratthā` in its temporal sense, along with other `pura`-derived words like `pure` and `purimāsu`, to refer to past existences.

16813.compound_construction: ubbegaṃ ca uttāsaṃ ca bhayaṃ ca apanūdana
16813.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This compound adjective describes something/someone that dispels anxiety (ubbega), terror (uttāsa), and fear (bhaya). The final element apanūdana is a verbal noun/adjective from apa + √nud "to remove". The preceding nouns are the objects being removed. The structure is effectively "removing of X, Y, and Z", used adjectivally to mean "one who removes X, Y, and Z". In the context "Ubbhegauttāsabhayāpanūdano, ridding them of fear...", it functions as an epithet describing the Buddha or Dhamma.
16813.example_1: ridding them of fear, terror, and danger,

54364.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The contextual sentence "Guttīsu rakkhāvaraṇesu ussuko" uses the word in the locative plural, describing someone eager in "safeguards and protections" or "guardings and securities".

59389.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence 'Tathā hi cakkāni samantanemini', 'samantanemini' is the nominative/accusative/vocative/instrumental/dative/ablative/locative plural neuter form of the adjective 'samantanemī', modifying 'cakkāni' (wheels).
59389.example_1: which is why he has wheels all rimmed around.

61448.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This compound is a Bahubbīhi, describing something that *has* one thousand spokes (sahassāni arāni yassa). In the contextual sentence, "sahassarāni" is neuter plural, agreeing with "cakkaratanāni" (wheel gems/treasures) understood from the context (although not explicitly in the provided line).

57593.meaning_1: having the hundred-fold mark of merits
57593.meaning_lit: having the mark of hundred merits
57593.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This adjective describes someone possessing a mark (lakkhaṇa) that is derived from or associated with merit (puñña), where "sata" (hundred) acts as an intensifier meaning "hundredfold" or indicating abundance of merit. The mark is a characteristic resulting from accumulated good deeds. It is one of the signs attributed to a Mahāpurisa, as seen in the contextual sentence referring to the young Gotama.
57593.example_1: seeing the prince <j>with the hundred-fold mark of merits,

44278.meaning_1: having a following; possessed of a retinue; having an entourage
44278.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This adjective is formed by adding the taddhita suffix `vant` (possessing) to the noun `parivāra` (retinue, following). The contextual sentence "Parivāravā hessati sattumaddano" means "He will have a following, subduing foes," where `Parivāravā` is the nominative singular masculine form of `parivāravant`.
44278.example_1: that he’d have a following, subduing foes,

57857.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The term is used in the contextual sentence to describe a quality of a powerful ruler, namely his ability to subdue enemies.
57857.example_1: that he’d have a following, subduing foes,

30181.meaning_1: devoted to him; obedient to him
30181.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The term "tassānuyuttā" in the contextual sentence (DN30) refers to the khattiyas who are devoted or obedient to the universal monarch (cakravartin king). The compound is formed from the genitive singular pronoun tassa and the adjective anuyutta (from anuyujjati). The sandhi between tassa and anuyutta results in tassānuyutta.
30181.example_1:
tathā hī cakkāni samantanemini,
sace na pabbajjamupeti tādiso,
vatteti cakkaṃ pathaviṃ pasāsati,
tassānuyantādha [tassānuyuttā idha,
tassānuyantā idha] bhavanti khattiyā.

30180.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, 'tassānuyantā' refers to the khattiyā (kings/warriors) who become subordinate to the Cakkavatti (universal monarch) if the Great Man chooses a worldly life. 'tassa' (his/to him) is in the genitive/dative case, hence the alutta chaṭṭhī tappurisa compound type.
30180.example_1:
tathā hī cakkāni samantanemini,
sace na pabbajjamupeti tādiso,
vatteti cakkaṃ pathaviṃ pasāsati,
tassānuyantādha [tassānuyuttā idha,
tassānuyantā idha] bhavanti khattiyā.

61620.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence "mahāyasaṃ saṃparivārayanti naṃ", the verb means "they surround him with great fame" or "great fame attends/accompanies him".
61620.example_1:
mahāyasaṃ saṃparivārayanti naṃ,
sace ca pabbajjamupeti tādiso,
nekkhammachandābhirato vicakkhaṇo,
devāmanussāsurasakkarakkhasā [sattarakkhasā sī. syāaṭṭhakathā oloketabbā].

34154.meaning_1: gods, humans, daemons, Sakka and goblins
34154.construction:
devā + manussa + asura + sakka + rakkhasa + ā
devāmanussāsurasakkarakkhasa + ā
34154.compound_construction: devā ca manussā ca asurā ca Sakko ca rakkhasā ca
34154.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is a Dvanda compound listing prominent types of beings in the Pāḷi cosmology: gods, humans, asuras, Sakka (king of devas), and rakkhasas. The form is masculine plural, referring to all of them collectively. In the contextual sentence from DN 30, this compound refers to the various groups of beings who would gather around a Great Man (Mahāpurisa), whether he remains a layman or becomes a Buddha.
34154.example_1:
mahāyasaṃ saṃparivārayanti naṃ,
sace ca pabbajjamupeti tādiso,
nekkhammachandābhirato vicakkhaṇo,
devāmanussāsurasakkarakkhasā [sattarakkhasā sī. syāaṭṭhakathā oloketabbā].

57768.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This compound appears in the text as a textual variant for sakkarakkhasā (Sakka and goblins). It is likely a dvandva compound combining satta (beings) and rakkhasa (goblins).
57768.example_1:
mahāyasaṃ saṃparivārayanti naṃ,
sace ca pabbajjamupeti tādiso,
nekkhammachandābhirato vicakkhaṇo,
devāmanussāsurasakkarakkhasā [sattarakkhasā sī. syāaṭṭhakathā oloketabbā].

65464.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, `syāaṭṭhakathā oloketabbā` means "the Thai commentary should be consulted". This refers to the edition of the commentary tradition preserved and printed in Thailand.
65464.example_1:
mahāyasaṃ saṃparivārayanti naṃ,
sace ca pabbajjamupeti tādiso,
nekkhammachandābhirato vicakkhaṇo,
devāmanussāsurasakkarakkhasā [sattarakkhasā sī. syāaṭṭhakathā oloketabbā].

56566.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is an imperfect verbal form of a compound verb 'to go to heaven'. The contextual sentence shows it means 'he went to heaven'.
56566.example_1: By that good conduct he went to heaven,

56567.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, "tena so sucaritena saggamagamāsi" means "By that good conduct, he went to heaven". The word describes the completed action of going to heaven.
56567.example_1:
māraṇavadhabhayattano [maraṇavadhabhayattano,
maraṇavadhabhayamattano] viditvā,
paṭivirato paraṃ māraṇāyahosi,
tena sucaritena saggamagamā [tena so sucaritena saggamagamāsi],
sukataphalavipākamanubhosi.

26367.meaning_1: having passed away; having fallen away
26367.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence "Caviya punaridhāgato samāno", caviya functions as an absolutive meaning "having passed away" or "passing away" before returning.
26367.example_1: Passing away, on his return to here,

46759.meaning_1: again come here; returned here again
46759.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, it refers to Caviya being reborn or returning to the place/state indicated by "idha".
46759.example_1: Passing away, on his return to here,

68441.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This adjective describes one of the 32 marks of a great man (mahāpurisalakkhaṇa), specifically relating to the heels being broad and long. The contextual sentence is part of a description of the Buddha's physical characteristics.
68441.example_1: his stretched heels are abundant and long,

63714.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, suju is used to mean "straight" describing the physical form of the person compared to Brahmā. It is a compound of su (well) and uju (straight).
63714.example_1: and like the Divinity, he’s straight and beautiful, <j>with well-formed limbs.

63705.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, 'sujātagatto' is used as an adjective describing 'Brahmā', meaning Brahmā has well-formed limbs. While grammatically this compound (`sujāta`-formed/born + `gatta`-limb) functions adjectivally to mean 'having well-formed limbs' (suggesting a Bahubbīhi interpretation in usage), the compound type is classified as Kammadhāraya ('well-formed limbs') consistent with other X-gatta compounds in the related entries.
63705.example_1: and like the Divinity, he’s straight and beautiful, <j>with well-formed limbs.

64433.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word susaṇṭhita is a compound of su (good) and saṇṭhita. Saṇṭhita is the past participle of saṃ+√ṭhā (to stand together, to be established). Thus, it literally means "well-stood" or "well-established/composed". In the context of a person, it means "well-formed", leading to the meaning "with good posture". The related entries show various derivations and forms from the saṃ+√ṭhā root family.
64433.example_1: Fair of arm, youthful, of good posture and breeding,

26782.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, 'cirayapanāya' is the dative or genitive singular form, meaning 'for longevity' or 'of longevity'. The meaning 'longevity' fits the context where characteristics of the boy are being described and predictions made about his future life.
26782.example_1:
subhujo susu susaṇṭhito sujāto,
mudutalunaṅguliyassa honti,
dīghā tībhi purisavaraggalakkhaṇehi,
cirayapanāya [cirayāpanāya] kumāramādisanti.

53770.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word `yapeti` is the causative of `yāti` (to go). Literally "causes to go", it commonly develops the meaning "to make endure", "to maintain", "to subsist", and thus "to live" or "to spend time". In the contextual sentence, `ciraṁ yapeti` means "lives long" or "spends a long time (living)". This is an intransitive use, often seen with adverbs of time or duration, or with the instrumental case indicating the means of sustenance, as seen in related entries.
53770.example_1: ‘As a householder he will live long;

66502.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the context "Yāpayati ca vasiddhibhāvanāya", the word is in the instrumental case, indicating the means or activity by which something is accomplished, hence "by developing mastery of psychic power". The compound combines vasa (mastery, control), iddhi (psychic power), and bhāvanā (development, cultivation). The internal compound vasiddhi likely means "mastery of psychic power", functioning as the object of development.
66502.example_1: mastery in the development of psychic power.

32781.meaning_1: fact of having longevity; fact of being long-lived
32781.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
dīghāyukatā is an abstract noun derived from the adjective dīghāyuka using the taddhita suffix -tā. The related word dīghāyuka means "long-lived" and is a compound (Kammadhāraya or Bahubbīhi). The context "dīghāyukatāya taṁ nimittan" uses the genitive case meaning "of longevity" or "of long life".
32781.example_1: Thus this is the sign of long life.’”

54739.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, "rasitānaṁ" is used in a list of adjectives describing various types of food and drink, indicating they are flavoursome or delicious.
54739.sutta_1: dātā ahosi paṇītānaṁ rasitānaṁ khādanīyānaṁ bhojanīyānaṁ sāyanīyānaṁ lehanīyānaṁ pānānaṁ.
54739.example_1: He was a donor of delicious and tasty cooked and fresh foods, and drinks that were sweet and succulent.

62418.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, sāyiyaṁ is listed alongside khajja, bhojja, and leyya, representing a category of desirable foods or tastes, best translated as delicacy or tasty food.
62418.example_1: “He used to give the very best of flavors—

14634.meaning_1: giver of the finest tasting delicacies
14634.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Refers to someone who provides or gives food of the highest quality and best taste.

26780.meaning_1: rejoices for a long time (in); is delighted for a long duration (in)
26780.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word is a compound of the adverb 'ciraṃ' (for a long time) and the verb 'abhippamodati' (rejoices greatly). The construction breaks down the verb 'abhippamodati' into its components: prefixes 'abhi' and 'pra', root '√mud', conjugational sign 'a', and ending 'ti'. The example sentence 'Nandane ciramabhippamodati' shows the verb used with the locative case 'Nandane', meaning 'he rejoiced for a long time in Nandana (heaven)'.
26780.example_1: he rejoiced long in Nandana heaven.

13703.meaning_1: attains here; possesses here; gets here
13703.meaning_lit: attains here; reaches here; gets here
13703.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The meaning "returns here; comes back here" in the original entry does not align well with the typical meaning of adhigacchati ("attains", "reaches", "gets") or the contextual sentence "Satta cussade idhādhigacchati" which describes possessing characteristics ("is rounded in seven places"). The corrected meaning "attains here; possesses here; gets here" fits the common usage of adhigacchati and the specific context of the Mahāpurisa marks. The phonetic change is `idha` + `adhigacchati` -> `idhādhigacchati` where the final `a` of `idha` merges with the initial `a` of `adhigacchati` forming `ā`.
13703.example_1: On returning to here, he is rounded in seven places,

48723.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word is a compound referring to someone expert in interpreting physical characteristics (byañjana) and other signs or omens (nimitta), often in the context of fortune-telling or physiognomy, as suggested by the contextual sentence about soothsayers (āhu byañjananimittakovidā).
48723.example_1: The soothsayers expert in signs declared:

29809.meaning_1: gets at that time; obtains then; (comm) gets that
29809.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Compound of the indeclinable tadā and the verb adhigacchati. The meaning in the contextual sentence "Pabbajjampi ca tadādhigacchati;" which translates to "But even if he goes forth he’ll get the same," aligns with the commentarial meaning "gets that" or "obtains that", referring to the consequence or outcome discussed, rather than strictly "gets at that time".
29809.example_1: But even if he goes forth he’ll get the same,

46221.meaning_1: kind words; endearing speech; speaking kindly
46221.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Used in DN30 as one of the four saṅgahavatthu (articles of service or bases of sympathy), specifically "peyavajjena" [piyavācena], instrumental neuter, meaning "by kind speech". The other three are dāna (giving), atthacariyā (beneficial conduct), and samānattatā (equality or impartiality). The form piyavāca appears to be a taddhita formation from the compound piya + vācā.
46221.example_1: 210. yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi janaṃ saṅgāhako ahosi, dānena peyyavajjena [piyavācena] atthacariyāya samānattatāya. so tassa kammassa kaṭattā … so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.

20507.meaning_1: good relationship by deed and conduct
20507.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This compound consists of kariya (deed), cariya (conduct), and susaṅgaha (good collection, inclusion, conciliation). It refers to the act of bringing people together or maintaining good relations through one's deeds and conduct. The contextual sentence "Kariyacariyasusaṅgahaṁ bahūnaṁ" (such action and conduct as brought people together for many) exemplifies this meaning.
20507.example_1: such action and conduct as brought people together,

3867.meaning_1: not disregarded; respected; esteemed; highly regarded
3867.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This word is a negative past participle of avamaññati (to disregard, think lightly of), formed with the negative prefix 'an-'. It means 'not disregarded' or 'respected'. In the contextual sentence 'Anavamatena guṇena', it means 'by his esteemed virtue'.
3867.example_1: he went to heaven due to his esteemed virtue.

28399.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, `jālino` is the genitive singular form of the adjective `jālī`, modifying `karacaraṇa` (hands and feet). This refers to the characteristic of having webbed fingers and toes (`jālāvanaddhakaracaraṇatā`), one of the 32 signs of a great man (mahāpurisalakkhaṇa). This entry, along with jālinī and jālī 1.1, derives from jāla ("net, web").

2275.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
A long compound describing physical beauty. In the contextual sentence, it modifies "hands and feet" (pāṇipādā), meaning they are very pleasing and beautiful to behold. Note the unusual neuter singular ending -aṁ used in apposition or adverbially with a masculine plural noun.
2275.example_1: hands and feet so tender and serried,

2769.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, 'atthūpasaṁhitaṁ vācaṁ' means 'meaningful speech', contrasting with 'dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ vācaṁ' ('principled speech'). It refers to speech that has substance, purpose, or is relevant to the topic or situation.
2769.sutta_1: atthūpasaṁhitaṁ dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā ahosi, bahujanaṁ nidaṁsesi, pāṇīnaṁ hitasukhāvaho dhammayāgī.
2769.example_1: His speech was meaningful and principled. He educated many people, bringing welfare and happiness, offering the teaching.

37188.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is the 3rd person singular aorist form of the causative verb nidaṃseti. The irregular causative stem daṃse derives from the root √dis (to show, point) with the prefix ni (down). The meaning "explained, taught, educated" in the contextual sentence fits well with the causative sense of "causing to show" or "pointing out" the Dhamma.
37188.sutta_1: atthūpasaṁhitaṁ dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā ahosi, bahujanaṁ nidaṁsesi, pāṇīnaṁ hitasukhāvaho dhammayāgī.
37188.example_1: His speech was meaningful and principled. He educated many people, bringing welfare and happiness, offering the teaching.

71231.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The compound `hitasukhāvaha` is formed from `hita` (welfare) and `sukha` (happiness/comfort) combined into a dvanda compound `hitasukha`, which then combines with `āvaha` (bringing). The entire compound functions as an adjective meaning "bringing welfare and happiness". In the context, `hitasukhāvaho` is the masculine nominative singular form agreeing with `dhammayāgī`.
71231.sutta_1: atthūpasaṁhitaṁ dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā ahosi, bahujanaṁ nidaṁsesi, pāṇīnaṁ hitasukhāvaho dhammayāgī.
71231.example_1: His speech was meaningful and principled. He educated many people, bringing welfare and happiness, offering the teaching.

34831.meaning_1: worshipping the Dhamma; offering the teaching
34831.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In this context, `dhammayāgī` refers to someone who deeply respects, practises, or teaches the Dhamma, here translated as "offering the teaching". It literally means "one who sacrifices or worships the Dhamma".
34831.sutta_1: atthūpasaṁhitaṁ dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā ahosi, bahujanaṁ nidaṁsesi, pāṇīnaṁ hitasukhāvaho dhammayāgī.
34831.example_1: His speech was meaningful and principled. He educated many people, bringing welfare and happiness, offering the teaching.

2658.meaning_1: meaningful and related to the Dhamma; principled; righteous; profitable and righteous
2658.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The compound atthadhammasahita describes something (here, a word) that is endowed with or accompanied by both "attha" (meaning, purpose, benefit) and "dhamma" (principle, righteousness, doctrine). The contextual sentence "Atthadhammasahitaṁ pure giraṁ" translates as "His word was meaningful and principled", illustrating this combined sense of practical benefit/meaning and adherence to righteous principle.

2659.meaning_1: meaningful and related to the Dhamma
2659.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Describes speech (giraṃ) that is beneficial/meaningful (attha) and in accordance with the Dhamma, as used in the contextual sentence DN30. The compound is a Bahubbhīhi meaning "that which is endowed with attha and dhamma".
2659.example_1:
atthadhammasahitaṃ  [atthadhammasaṃhitaṃ,
atthadhammupasaṃhitaṃ] pure giraṃ,
erayaṃ bahujanaṃ nidaṃsayi,
pāṇinaṃ hitasukhāvaho ahu,
dhammayāgamayajī [dhammayāgaṃ assaji] amaccharī.

17988.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The form 'erayaṁ' in the contextual sentence is an inflected form (likely accusative singular or nominative/accusative feminine singular) of the present participle 'erayanta'. It functions transitively, taking 'bahujanaṁ' (accusative) as its object. The meaning 'moving' fits the context of influencing people with explanations. The root √īr means 'to move', and the causal stem 'eraya' means 'to cause to move'.
17988.example_1: moving the people with his explanations.

37187.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is an aorist form from the causative root ni-dis. The root shows irregular changes in the causative stem formation (daṃsaya or dasse/daṃse). The ending '-ayi' is a less common alternative aorist ending, usually found in verse, compared to the more standard '-esi' seen in 'nidaṃsesi'. In the contextual sentence, 'Erayaṁ bahujanaṁ nidaṃsayi', it means 'He showed (displayed/explained) the great multitude (people)'.
37187.example_1: moving the people with his explanations.

14650.meaning_1: fact of being the highest and foremost; excellence and supremacy
14650.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The meaning "excellence and supremacy" comes from the contextual sentence "Uttamappamukhatāya vindati", where it is used in the instrumental/ablative case meaning "obtains by means of excellence and supremacy". The compound structure is (Uttama-Pamukha) + -tā, forming an abstract noun from the compound "uttamappamukha". The compound "uttamappamukha" itself means "highest-foremost". While morphologically it might look like a Kammadhāraya, the meaning "highest and foremost" is often treated as a Dvanda of the qualities `uttamatā` and `pamukhatā`, hence the compound type and construction fields reflecting this semantic interpretation.

16791.meaning_lit: having hair that has risen upward
16791.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This compound describes a state of having hair that stands on end. The components literally mean "upward + risen + having hair". In the contextual sentence, it describes a hare whose hairs stand upright, likely due to fear or alertness.

62238.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
A kammadhāraya compound of sādhu (well, properly) and saṇṭhita (established, formed, standing). The literal meaning "well established/formed" aligns well with the contextual sentence describing "well-formed ankles".
62238.example_1: and his ankles stand out well.

52117.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is a Tatiyā Tappurisa compound. The compound `maṃsalohita` (flesh and blood) is treated as the instrumental cause ('by flesh and blood') for being 'ācita' (filled/covered). Thus, 'filled or covered by flesh and blood'. In the contextual sentence, 'Maṁsalohitācitā' describes the body as 'swollen with flesh and blood'.
52117.example_1: Swollen with flesh and blood, encased in skin,

5617.meaning_1: of non-inferior exertion; noble; excellent; peerless
5617.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, 'anomanikkamo' is the masculine singular nominative form, agreeing with 'pabbajjo' (going forth, renunciation - which is masculine). It means the renunciation/going forth is of 'non-inferior exertion' or is 'noble/excellent'.
5617.example_1: But going forth the peerless renunciate

58897.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence 'Aggataṁ vajati sabbapāṇinaṁ', 'sabbapāṇinaṁ' is the dative/genitive plural form of 'sabbapāṇī', meaning 'of all living beings' or 'for all living beings'. The sentence means '[He] turns into the best of all creatures'.
58897.example_1: turns into the best of all creatures.

58947.meaning_1: conquering the whole world; mastering the entire universe
58947.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Compound gerund formed from sabbalokaṃ (accusative of sabbaloka) and abhibhuyya (gerund of abhibhavati). Meaning in context: "having mastered the whole world". Sandhi ṃ+a > ma.
58947.example_1: he’ll live having mastered the whole world.”

54884.meaning_1: part of a king; royal component
54884.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, rājaṅgāni refers to components, factors, or attributes associated with kingship or belonging to a king, listed alongside things worthy of, used by, or befitting a king.
54884.sutta_1: Yāni tāni rājārahāni rājaṅgāni rājūpabhogāni rājānucchavikāni tāni khippaṁ paṭilabhati.
54884.example_1: He quickly obtains the things worthy of a king, the factors, supports, and things befitting a king.

54981.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This compound consists of rāja (king) and upabhoga (use, enjoyment). The sandhi between the final vowel of rāja (a) and the initial vowel of upabhoga (u) results in ū. The compound is a Catutthī Tatpurisa, indicating purpose or utility for the king. In the contextual sentence, `rājūpabhogāni` is the plural form of the adjective modifying the things (`tāni`) that are useful for the king.
54981.sutta_1: Yāni tāni rājārahāni rājaṅgāni rājūpabhogāni rājānucchavikāni tāni khippaṁ paṭilabhati.
54981.example_1: He quickly obtains the things worthy of a king, the factors, supports, and things befitting a king.

54954.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The compound rājānucchavika is formed from rājā (king) and anucchavika (suitable, proper). It is a tatpurisa compound specifying suitability for a king, which in the genitive case (chaṭṭhī) would be "of the king" or "for the king". In the context provided, "rājānucchavikāni tāni" refers to things suitable for a king (neuter plural). The grammatical fields reflect this structure.
54954.sutta_1: Yāni tāni rājārahāni rājaṅgāni rājūpabhogāni rājānucchavikāni tāni khippaṁ paṭilabhati.
54954.example_1: He quickly obtains the things worthy of a king, the factors, supports, and things befitting a king.

59251.meaning_1: worthy of an ascetic; fit for a monk
59251.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, samaṇārahāni is the neuter plural form of the adjective, agreeing with the neuter plural nouns samaṇaṅgāni, samaṇūpabhogāni, and samaṇānucchavikāni. It describes qualities, possessions, and practices that are fitting or appropriate for an ascetic or monk.
59251.sutta_1: Yāni tāni samaṇārahāni samaṇaṅgāni samaṇūpabhogāni samaṇānucchavikāni, tāni khippaṁ paṭilabhati.
59251.example_1: He quickly obtains the things worthy of an ascetic, the factors, supports, and things befitting an ascetic.

59186.meaning_1: a factor of an ascetic; an ascetic practice
59186.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, samaṇaṅgāni functions as a neuter plural noun referring to ascetic practices or factors that constitute being an ascetic. This aligns with other dhamma-related or practice-related compounds ending in -aṅga, which are often neuter nouns (e.g., aṭṭhaṅga, dhutaṅga). The entry lists the pos as "adj", and pattern as "a adj", which allows for neuter declension (samaṇaṅgaṃ, samaṇaṅgāni).
59186.sutta_1: Yāni tāni samaṇārahāni samaṇaṅgāni samaṇūpabhogāni samaṇānucchavikāni, tāni khippaṁ paṭilabhati.
59186.example_1: He quickly obtains the things worthy of an ascetic, the factors, supports, and things befitting an ascetic.

59256.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, samaṇūpabhogāni (neuter plural) describes things ("tāni", referring to "samaṇaṅgāni") that are suitable or useful for ascetics.
59256.sutta_1: Yāni tāni samaṇārahāni samaṇaṅgāni samaṇūpabhogāni samaṇānucchavikāni, tāni khippaṁ paṭilabhati.
59256.example_1: He quickly obtains the things worthy of an ascetic, the factors, supports, and things befitting an ascetic.

59250.meaning_1: suitable for an ascetic; fit for a monk
59250.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the context, samaṇānucchavikāni modifies things (tāni) befitting an ascetic, alongside samaṇārahāni, samaṇaṅgāni, samaṇūpabhogāni.
59250.sutta_1: Yāni tāni samaṇārahāni samaṇaṅgāni samaṇūpabhogāni samaṇānucchavikāni, tāni khippaṁ paṭilabhati.
59250.example_1: He quickly obtains the things worthy of an ascetic, the factors, supports, and things befitting an ascetic.

67590.meaning_1: should understand; could understand; would understand; comprehend
67590.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
vijāneyyu is the 3rd person plural optative form of vijānāti. The ending -eyyu is an alternative spelling/form of -eyyuṃ, common in verse. The context asks how "they" (lahunti) would understand quickly.
67590.example_1:
sippesu vijjācaraṇesu kammesu [kammasu],
kathaṃ vijāneyyuṃ [vijāneyya,
vijāneyyu] lahunti icchati,
yadūpaghātāya na hoti kassaci,
vāceti khippaṃ na ciraṃ kilissati.

51173.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, manuññā describes calves and is translated as elegant, fitting the meaning of beautiful or pleasant to the eye. The compound structure suggests "agreeable to the mind (manas)".
51173.example_1: he gains prominent and elegant calves.

4860.meaning_1: risen up successively; gradually swelling; gradually growing
4860.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Compound formed from the adverb anupubbaṃ ("successively") and the past participle uggata ("risen", "gone up"). The sandhi ṃu > mu is regular. Meaning fits the contextual sentence describing how the "spirals" (vaṭṭā) grow or swell.

63587.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the context sentence "Uddhaggalomā sukhumattacotthatā", the adjective sukhumattacotthatā (masc. nom. pl.) modifies uddhaggalomā (masc. nom. pl.), describing hairs that are fine and rising, and are covered by delicate skin. The implied subject is the body (presumably of a great man) from which these hairs arise and which is covered by this fine skin.
63587.example_1: he’s covered in fine rising hairs.

25224.meaning_1: suitable for the home; conforming to household life
25224.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, gehānulomāni (neuter plural) refers to things that are suitable for or conform to household life.
25224.example_1: If he desires the things fitting the household life,

6238.meaning_1: not ordaining; not renouncing (the household life)
6238.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, `Apabbajaṁ` is the accusative singular form of `apabbajanta`, used here likely adverbially or as a substantive.
6238.example_1: not going forth, they’ll quickly be his.

63580.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This word is one of the 32 marks of a Great Man (mahāpurisalakkhaṇa), referring to the characteristic of having very delicate skin. The contextual sentence lists it simply as one of these marks.

64526.meaning_1: who wants to hear; who wishes to listen
64526.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The contextual sentence "Sussūsitā pabbajitaṁ upāsitā" means "Keen to learn, he waited on renunciates". Here, "keen to learn" is a fitting translation for "one who wishes to hear/listen", implying a desire to learn from the renunciates. The form "sussūsitā" is the nominative singular masculine of "sussūsitar".
64526.example_1: Keen to learn, he waited on renunciates,

16435.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Upāsitar is an agent noun derived from upāsati. The nominative singular is upāsitā. In the contextual sentence "Sussūsitā pabbajitaṁ upāsitā", upāsitā functions as the subject (implied or part of the main clause structure) meaning "one who attended" or "attendant", referring to waiting upon or serving the renunciates.
16435.example_1: Keen to learn, he waited on renunciates,

2662.meaning_1: another meaning; different meaning; one with a different purpose/intent
2662.compound_construction: one who has a different attha
2662.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Atthantara is a compound of attha (meaning, purpose, intent) and antara (other, different). As an adjective, it describes someone or something as having a different meaning or purpose. In the contextual sentence "Atthantaro atthakathaṁ nisāmayi", Atthantaro is nominative singular masculine, likely referring to the subject as "one with a different intent" who listened to the explanation. The provided English translation seems to interpret Atthantaro differently from its literal meaning.
2662.example_1: heeding their explanation with pure intent.

2610.meaning_lit: telling of the meaning; explanation of purpose
2610.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The term `atthakathā` refers to the traditional commentaries on the Pāḷi Canon. In the contextual sentence "Atthantaro atthakathaṁ nisāmayi", it is used in the accusative singular `atthakathaṃ` and means "explanation", fitting the general sense of the word. The subject (atthantaro) is listening to an explanation.
2610.example_1: heeding their explanation with pure intent.

38186.meaning_1: heeded; listened attentively; paid close attention
38186.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is the 3rd person singular aorist form of the causative verb derived from ni + √sam. The meaning "heeded" or "listened attentively" fits the context of the sentence "Atthantaro atthakathaṁ nisāmayi" (Another heeded the explanation). It takes the accusative case, as shown by atthakathaṁ.
38186.example_1: heeding their explanation with pure intent.

40022.meaning_1: done for the sake of obtaining wisdom; done for the purpose of acquiring knowledge
40022.meaning_lit: made/done for the acquisition of knowledge/wisdom
40022.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The contextual sentence uses the instrumental form paññāpaṭilābhagatena, suggesting a link to gata ('gone to' or 'obtained'), but the commentary indicates the reading paññāpaṭilābhakatena ('done for the acquisition of wisdom'). This entry follows the commentary's reading. It describes an action (kamma) performed with the specific purpose of gaining wisdom, linking a physical characteristic (fine skin) to a spiritually motivated deed.
40022.example_1:
paññāpaṭilābhagatena [paññāpaṭilābhakatena ṭīkā oloketabbā] kammunā,
manussabhūto sukhumacchavī ahu,
byākaṃsu uppādanimittakovidā,
sukhumāni atthāni avecca dakkhiti.

10772.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the context 'Sukhumāni atthāni avecca dakkhiti' (He’ll discern delicate matters), 'avecca' acts as a gerund or absolutive modifying 'dakkhiti' (will discern), indicating that the discerning happens *by means of* understanding or penetrating the subtle matters.

2726.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The compound atthānusiṭṭhi is a sattamī tappurisa, meaning "instruction in/regarding benefit or affairs". The sandhi involves the lengthening of the final 'a' of attha to 'ā' before anusiṭṭhi. In the contextual sentence, "atthānusiṭṭhīsu pariggahesu ca", it refers to instruction or education received in practical affairs or the management of material possessions, contributing to the meaning of "administration" or "governance" in that context.
2726.example_1: Among those with material things <j>who have been educated,

36416.meaning_1: didn't lose one's temper; didn't get angry; didn't curse angrily; didn't abuse; didn't swear; (comm) didn't stick
36416.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The aorist negation of abhisajjati. In the contextual sentence, it means "didn't lose his temper" or "didn't get angry", reflecting one of the primary meanings of the base verb negated. The grammatical form matches the aorist form abhisajji preceded by the negative particle na.
36416.sutta_1: bahumpi vutto samāno nābhisajji na kuppi na byāpajji na patitthīyi, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi.
36416.example_1: Even when heavily criticized he didn’t lose his temper, become annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

45942.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the context of dn30:1.28.4, pāvuraṇānaṁ refers to "blankets" alongside "mats" (attharaṇānaṁ) and various types of fine cloths, indicating a type of covering used for warmth or bedding.
45942.sutta_1: Dātā ca ahosi sukhumānaṁ mudukānaṁ attharaṇānaṁ pāvuraṇānaṁ khomasukhumānaṁ kappāsikasukhumānaṁ koseyyasukhumānaṁ kambalasukhumānaṁ.
45942.example_1: He donated soft and fine mats and blankets, and fine cloths of linen, cotton, silk, and wool.

75652.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This aorist form can convey both general determination/resolution and the act of fixing one's attention, as shown in the two entries adhiṭṭhahi 1 and 2. The contextual sentence reflects the "fixed attention" meaning, aligning with adhiṭṭhahi 1.
75652.example_1: “Fixated on good will, he gave gifts.

63697.meaning_1: smooth; fine; soft; having a good surface/complexion
63697.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence "vatthāni sukhumāni succhavīni", succhavīni (plural of succhavī) modifies "vatthāni" (clothes). It means the clothes are smooth or fine to the touch, having a pleasant surface, reflecting the meaning "smooth; fine; soft".
63697.example_1: In an earlier life he poured forth cloth

47014.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Compound of purimatara (comparative of purima, earlier) and bhava (existence). Used in the contextual sentence in the locative singular: Purimatarabhave (in the earlier existence).

8357.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence 'Purimatarabhave ṭhito abhivissaji', the word means 'he gave away' or 'he doled out' [something understood from context] while standing in a former existence. The English translation provided 'fine and soft to touch,' does not correspond to this phrase.

64331.family_set: types of supernatural beings; names of deities
64331.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word sura is derived from the root √sur meaning "to shine". In the contextual sentence, suro is the nominative singular form, meaning "a god".
64331.example_1: like a god pouring rain on this broad earth.

15854.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The contextual sentence uses the aorist form "upapajji" ("was reborn"), which is related to the gerund "upapajja" ("being reborn"). The sentence fragment "upapajji [upapajja]" suggests that "upapajja" is the base form or a related variant indicated in the source text, although the finite verb used is the aorist.
15854.example_1:
taṃ katvāna ito cuto dibbaṃ,
upapajji [upapajja] sukataphalavipākamanubhutvā,
kanakatanusannibho idhābhibhavati,
suravarataroriva indo.

19944.meaning_1: resembling a golden body; shining like gold
19944.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
The word is a compound describing something or someone as resembling a body made of gold or shining like gold. In the context, it describes the "figure" (rūpa, perhaps implied) that someone wins, which shines like honey-yellow gold.
19944.example_1: Here he wins a figure shining like honey-yellow gold,

6239.meaning_1: not ordaining; not renouncing (the household life)
6239.construction:
na > a + pa + √vaj > baj + ya
na + pabbajja
6239.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, 'apabbajja' functions adverbially, describing the condition of the man staying in the house.
6239.example_1: If that man stays in the house, not wishing to go forth,

8315.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Contextual sentence uses `abhivasana-varataraṃ` as a compound, describing the excellent way a universal monarch (cakkavatti) inhabits or rules their realm/possessions, contrasting with a reclusive Buddha. The lemma `abhivasana` itself means dwelling or inhabiting.
8315.example_1:
gehañcāvasati naro apabbajja,
micchaṃ mahatimahiṃ anusāsati [pasāsati],
pasayha sahidha sattaratanaṃ [pasayha abhivasana-varataraṃ],
paṭilabhati vimala [vipula,
vipulaṃ] sukhumacchaviṃ suciñca.

66356.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This entry describes varatara in its absolute, superlative-like sense ("very best", "finest"), distinct from varatara 1 ("better"). In the contextual sentence, it appears in the variant reading [pasayha abhivasana-varataraṃ], likely meaning "finest abode" or similar, showing its use in compounds.
66356.example_1:
gehañcāvasati naro apabbajja,
micchaṃ mahatimahiṃ anusāsati [pasāsati],
pasayha sahidha sattaratanaṃ [pasayha abhivasana-varataraṃ],
paṭilabhati vimala [vipula,
vipulaṃ] sukhumacchaviṃ suciñca.

63579.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This entry is for the feminine noun "delicate skin", distinguished from the adjective "having delicate skin" (sukhumacchavi 1). In the contextual sentence, it appears in the accusative singular (sukhumacchaviṃ) describing the skin itself obtained by the person.
63579.example_1:
gehañcāvasati naro apabbajja,
micchaṃ mahatimahiṃ anusāsati [pasāsati],
pasayha sahidha sattaratanaṃ [pasayha abhivasana-varataraṃ],
paṭilabhati vimala [vipula,
vipulaṃ] sukhumacchaviṃ suciñca.

1059.meaning_1: clothing, cloth and the finest cloak
1059.compound_construction: acchādana ca vattha ca mokkhapāvuraṇa ca
1059.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is a compound combining acchādana (covering/clothing), vattha (cloth/garment), mokkha (finest/best, from Skt. mukhya), and pāvuraṇa (cloak/outer garment). The compound is likely a Dvanda list of garment types, with mokkha modifying pāvuraṇa or the collection, resulting in "clothing, cloth, and the finest cloak/garments". The contextual sentence lists them as separate items received: "robes, cloth, and the finest garments", supporting the interpretation as a collection of items including the best type of outer garment.
1059.example_1: He receives robes, cloth, and the finest garments

3923.construction:
na > an + agāra + iya + tā
anāgāriya + tā
3923.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, anāgāriyataṁ is the accusative singular form of anāgāriyatā, referring to the state of homelessness adopted by someone who has renounced the household life to become a religious ascetic (monk or nun). This is the meaning conveyed by "the life gone forth".
3923.example_1: if he chooses the life gone forth.

61483.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
In the contextual sentence, 'Sahito purimakataphalaṁ anubhavati', 'sahito' (nominative singular masculine) modifies the implied subject and means 'accompanied by' or 'together with' the result of past deeds. It shows the subject is experiencing something while being accompanied by or connected to the past deeds' fruit.
61483.example_1: For he still partakes of past deed’s fruit;

47005.meaning_1: fruit of former deeds; consequence of past actions
47005.meaning_lit: fruit of what was done formerly
47005.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Refers to the results or consequences experienced in the present life due to actions performed in past lives or earlier in the current life. The contextual sentence "For he still partakes of past deed’s fruit" directly illustrates this meaning.
47005.example_1: For he still partakes of past deed’s fruit;

23223.meaning_1: auspicious mark of sheathed genitals; the mark of the privates being retracted
23223.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
This is the 14th of the 32 Marks of a Great Man (Mahāpurisalakkhaṇa), indicating that the genitals are retracted into the body like an elephant's, rather than hanging externally. 'Kosohita' means 'sheathed' or 'retracted' ('kosa' sheath + 'ohita' placed). 'Guyha' means 'private parts' or 'genitals'. 'Vattha' likely refers to the pelvic region, possibly a variant of 'vatthi', or meaning 'covered' area. The compound 'kosohitavatthaguyha' thus refers to the 'sheathed private parts in the pelvic region'. The full compound is a Tatpurisa meaning 'the mark OF the sheathed private parts in the pelvic region'.
